flat.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: smooth and level, without raised or hollow areas, and not sloping or curving
flat.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The countryside near there is flat as a pancake (=very flat).
Work on a clean, flat surface.
flat.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a flat rate, amount of money etc is fixed and does not change or have anything added to it
flat.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Clients are charged a flat rate of £250 annually.
We charge a flat fee for car hire.
flat.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a flat tyre or ball has no air or not enough air in it
flat.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: not very deep, thick, or high, especially in comparison to its width or length
flat.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The cake came out of the oven flat, not fluffy.
flat.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: a drink that is flat does not taste fresh because it has no more bubbles of gas in it
flat.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: a performance, book etc that is flat lacks interest, excitement, or energy
flat.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Arsenal looked flat for large parts of the game.
flat.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: a flat battery has lost its electrical power
flat.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Have you checked that the batteries haven’t gone flat (=become flat)?
flat.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: if prices, economic conditions, trade etc are flat, they have not increased or improved over a period of time
flat.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Analysts are expecting flat sales in the coming months.
flat.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if a musical note is flat, it is played or sung slightly lower than it should be
flat.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: not showing much emotion, or not changing much in sound as you speak
flat.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: ‘He’s dead, ’ she said in a flat voice.
flat.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: flat shoes have very low heels
flat.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: having little variety of light and dark
flat.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: Flat lighting is typical of Avedon’s portraits.
flat.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: flat
on one level, without any holes or raised areas, and not sloping or curving
a flat roof
a flat screen
Before you lay the tiles, make sure that the ground is completely flat.
level
not sloping in any direction, so that every part is at the same height
Is the top of this picture level?
After four hours coming down the mountain, I was glad to be back on level ground.
without any holes or raised areas – used especially when saying how something feels when you touch it
her lovely smooth skin
I ran my hand across the animal’s smooth fur.
even
without any holes or raised areas
Apply the paint to an even surface.
Be careful – the path is not very even here.
horizontal
going straight across and not sloping
a horizontal line
Raise both arms to a horizontal position.
flat.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a place for people to live that consists of a set of rooms that are part of a larger building
flat.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: They have a flat in Crouch End.
The building was knocked down to make way for a block of flats (=a large building with many flats in it).
flat.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a tyre that does not have enough air inside
flat.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Damn, the car has a flat.
He stopped to change a flat.
flat.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a musical note that is one semitone lower than a particular note
flat.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: the sign (Ƅ) in written music that shows that a note is one semitone lower than a particular note
flat.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: ADJECTIVES/NOUN + flat
The flat was too small for the three of them.
big/spacious
It was a big flat with eight or nine rooms.
cramped/poky
She spends most days shut up in a poky flat looking after her disabled Mum.
a one-bedroom/two-bedroom etc flat
She lived in a one-bedroom flat in Clapham.
a one-room/two-room etc flat
Their home is a humble two-room flat.
a ground-floor/first-floor/second-floor etc flat
We’re moving into a first-floor flat.
a basement flat
They lived in a basement flat in South London.
a studio flat
I might just be able to afford a tiny studio flat.
high-rise flats
Many high-rise flats were built in the 1970s.
a rented flat
He returned to his rented flat in Cheltenham.
a luxury flat
Laura shares a luxury flat with her sister Chloe.
a self-contained flat
We rented a self-contained flat in the city centre.
a furnished/unfurnished flat
She found a job and a furnished flat.
a holiday flat
The building has been converted into three holiday flats.
a block of flats
At the time, I lived in a block of flats in St John’s Wood.
live in a flat
Terry lived in a flat on the second floor.
buy a flat
I had planned to buy a flat with Geraldine.
rent a flat
Renting a flat can be very expensive in this part of town.
move into a flat
They move into their new flat next week.
own a flat
The couple own their own flat in Peebles.
flat.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: in a position in which the surface of something is against another surface without curving or sloping
flat.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The bed can be folded flat for storage.
He lay flat on the floor.
That night I lay flat on my back and stared up at the ceiling.
flat.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: if you sing or play music flat, you sing or play slightly lower than the correct note so that the sound is unpleasant
flat.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: a flat fee, price etc is fixed and does not change or have anything added to it
flat.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: We charge a flat fee for car hire.
Subscribers to the service have to pay a flat charge each month.
flat.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: if a market, economy etc is flat or sales are flat, levels of trade or sales are not increasing
flat.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: In the USA, car sales were flat although truck sales increased.
As demand for the company’s products stays flat and costs remain high, half-year profits have fallen by 70% to £15.1 million.
flat.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: if the stockmarket is flat, prices are not rising or falling
flat.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: The share market closed flat after spending the day trapped in a 10 point range.
flat.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: a place where people live that consists of a set of rooms, usually on one floor, which are part of a larger building
flat.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: Prices start from £89,995 for one-bedroom flats.
The building was knocked down to make way for a block of flats (=a large building divided into many separate flats).
flat.translation[5].definitions[0].defin: if something you are doing or planning falls flat, it is unsuccessful
flat.translation[5].definitions[0].examp: Their plans to build a retirement home in Spain fell flat.
flat.translation[5].definitions[1].defin: if you work flat out, you work as fast as possible
flat.translation[5].definitions[1].examp: Working flat out, the men completed the work by about ten-thirty on Saturday morning.
